reviewText:
I really want to recommend this game, because it is Magical Drop, and Magical Drop is one of the best puzzle games out there (1000x better than Bust a Move, which is so meh). And this is Magical Drop, but it's Magical Drop without Puzzle Mode, or the Quest Mode that was added in Magical Drop 3.

All it has available is Versus Mode, either in Story Mode or Online. Which is basically where you play Magical Drop against an npc or other player, to see who can get the most matches the fastest.

Puzzle Mode was just an endless mode by yourself, to see how long you could keep going before the game beat you. It got progressively harder as you went along, and it was the most fun mode in the game.

Quest mode added a small RPG element, or more board game element to the game, although not sure if that would work the same without requiring quarters like the arcade version did.

ANYWAY, for $.99 ($.89 on sale), the game is pretty fun, but without Puzzle Mode, it's just not complete. Until that is fixed, I can't really recommend it.

OH ALSO, this game does not like to run in full screen mode on large monitors, so run it windowed.

reviewText:
Don't judge a book by its cover, this game is really REALLY difficult!

This is an intense fast-paced puzzle game where you pick up lines of blocks to match them against each other, while also sending garbage blocks to your opponent to try and make their pile go over their limit before they do the same to you.  There is also another style of playing the game, as the game developers combined their alternate puzzle game and fused it into this game, so you could actually be playing two different game modes at the exact same time!  I can't exactly say in words how frantic this game is, but I think most people that picked this game up at the same time as me only played through it once and ended up never beating it because the game mechanics were too difficult.

At later stages of the game, the only way to beat your opponents are by chaining together increasingly large and complex combos, which would make this game incredibly frustrating for anyone who expected this to be a casual game.

I would highly recommend anyone to try to find some videos of this game before buying it, because I think a lot of people won't have the patience to actually sit down and try to beat it, even if there are infinite continues (which is also a mechanic of unlocking some bosses/achievements - aka no death runs).  It's a fun game overall though, and I think I did get exactly what I paid for.

Just don't underestimate it because of how it looks!

Really good game. The gameplay is solid, the art and music are passable, but the gameplay makes up for all of it.  It's fast, fluid and very simple to get into.  Definite buy if you're into Puzzle bobble/Bustamove or fast paced puzzle games like puyo puyo.


The core gameplay is to pull orbs down from the top of the screen and then make columns of at least 3 of the same colour. If the column is connected to any more orbs of the same colour they'll all pop, and the goal is to reach 200 popped orbs before the other player, or make them mess up and overload their side with orbs.

If you play as bruce you get a mix of Puzzle bobble mechanics and some new twists which make it really enjoyable, his playstyle is harder to explain but is a lot of fun in action.

The AI is competant and will challenge you thoroughly, and there's local AND online multiplayer modes so you can play with your friends.

The story mode is about what you'd expect from this style of game. A short conversation between two characters followed by a duel, but each story mode is a decent length (about 12 levels) and has pretty good difficulty progression.

All in all, I give this game a solid 8/10.

reviewText:
I could forgive everything people had to say about this game that was bad but for the following: the fundamental gameplay is broken, and that for the single simple reason that there's a delay between catching a ball and being able to move. I haven't played a Magical Drop game since MG3 on the Neo Geo and Magical Drop Pocket on the Neo Geo Pocket Color, but neither of those games had any delay, which made it possible to control your character and move to the side however many spaces you needed to to line up a shot. You could do this reliably, making chains very possible. In this version, there's a half-second delay and no visual cue to let you know the character has caught the ball and can move, making chains almost impossible. I consider myself a pretty decent player, but I can't play this at all. It's basically a different game because of this.

Other issues abound. According to another Japanese reviewer here, the Japanese translation reads like auto-translation. I can say for certain that subtitles do not display at all during story mode in Japanese. The game also crashed to desktop 3 times for me in the first few minutes, and according to another Japanese reviewer, this happens when the game is set to Japanese. You must play in English to get the game to work. Even after buying the game, it still acts as though it's the demo, giving you options to unlock the full game.

I'd forgive all of this if the core gameplay worked well. It doesn't. If you're absolutely brand-new to Magical Drop, perhaps you could forgive it. I don't see how that's possible if you've already been playing the series for years.

A shame, too, as this seems like it had real potential. I'm very sad to learn that this never got reliably improved upon, and even more frustrated that no other reviewers mentioned the control delay which, for me, makes the game an absolute chore to play (it feels significantly slower and less frantic than prior games in the series).
